column2: The little room was resplendent one night with a fire which flamed and flickered gloriously.
column3: The little room was resplendent one night with a fire which flamed and flickered gloriously.

column2: It set in motion many shadows which had their home in the corners of the walls, and bade them cease their sullenness and come forth to dance in the riot of the hour.
column3: It set in motion many shadows which had their home in the corners of the walls, and bade them cease their sullenness and come forth to dance in the riot of the hour.

column2: And so each shadow found its partner in a ray of firelight, and there they danced.
column3: And so each shadow found its partner in a ray of firelight, and there they danced.

column2: They danced about the tangled front of the big bison's head which hung upon the wall.
column3: They danced about the tangled front of the big bison's head which hung upon the wall.

column2: They crossed the grinning skull of the gray wolf.
column3: They crossed the grinning skull of the gray wolf.

column2: They softened the eyes of the antelope's head, and made dark lines behind the long-tined antlers of the elk and of the deer.
column3: They softened the eyes of the antelope's head, and made dark lines behind the long tined antlers of the elk and of the deer.

column2: They brought forth to view in alternate eclipse and definition the great, grim bear's head which hung above the mantel.
column3: They brought forth to view in alternate eclipse and definition the great, grim bear's head which hung above the mantel.

column2: Every trophy gathered in years of the chase, once perhaps prized, now perhaps forgotten, was brought into evidence, nor could one escape noting each one, and giving to each, for this one night more, the story which belonged to it.
column3: Every trophy gathered in years of the chase, once perhaps prized, now perhaps forgotten, was brought into evidence, nor could one escape noting each one, and giving to each, for this one night more, the story which belonged to it.

column2: I sat and looked upon them all, and so there passed a panorama of the years.
column3: I sat and looked upon them all, and so there passed a panorama of the years.

column2: There, thought I, "is the stag which once fell far in the pine woods of the North.
column3: There, thought I, "is the stag which once fell far in the pine woods of the North.

column2: This antelope takes me back to the hard, white Plains.
column3: This antelope takes me back to the hard, white Plains.

column2: These huge antlers could grow only amid the forests of the Rockies.
column3: These huge antlers could grow only amid the forests of the Rockies.

column2: That wolf--how many of the hounds he mangled, I remember; and the giant bear, it was a good fight he made, perhaps dangerous, had the old rifle there been less sure. Yes, yes, of course, I could recall each incident.
column3: That wolf-how many of the hounds he mangled, I remember; and the giant bear, it was a good fight he made, perhaps dangerous, had the old rifle there been less sure. Yes, yes, of course, I could recall each incident.

column2: Of course, they all were thrilling, exciting, delightful, glorious, all those things.
column3: Of course, they all were thrilling, exciting, delightful, glorious, all those things.

column2: Of course, the heart must have leaped in those days.
column3: Of course, the heart must have leaped in those days.

column2: The blood must have surged, in those moments.
column3: The blood must have surged, in those moments.

column2: The pulse must have grown hard, the mouth must have been dry with the ardor of the chase, at those times.
column3: The pulse must have grown hard, the mouth must have been dry with the ardor of the chase, at those times.

column2: But now?
column3: But now?

column2: But why?
column3: But why?

column2: Does the heart leap to-night, do the veins fill with the rush of the blood, tumultuous in the joy of stimulus or danger?
column3: Does the heart leap to night, do the veins fill with the rush of the blood, tumultuous in the joy of stimulus or danger?

column2: Why does not the old eagerness come back?
column3: Why does not the old eagerness come back?

column2: Which of these trophies is the one to bring this back again?
column3: Which of these trophies is the one to bring this back again?

column2: To which of these grim, silent heads belongs the keenest story?"
column3: To which of these grim, silent heads belongs the keenest story?"

column2: I know, said the Singing Mouse, which unknown to me had come and placed itself upon the table.
column3: I know, said the Singing Mouse, which unknown to me had come and placed itself upon the table.

column2: I know. And it climbed upon my arm which lay across the table.
column3: I know. And it climbed upon my arm which lay across the table.

column2: The fire shone fair upon its little form, so that in silhouette its outline was delicate and keen as an image cut from the fiery heart of a noble opal stone.
column3: The fire shone fair upon its little form, so that in silhouette its outline was delicate and keen as an image cut from the fiery heart of a noble opal stone.

column2: And what is it that you know? I asked.
column3: And what is it that you know? I asked.

column2: Maker of dreams, tell me what you know to-night.
column3: Maker of dreams, tell me what you know to night.

column2: The Singing Mouse balanced and moved itself in harmony with the beat of the fire's rays.
column3: The Singing Mouse balanced and moved itself in harmony with the beat of the fire's rays.

column2: I looked at it so closely that a dream came upon my eyes, so that the voice of the Singing Mouse sounded far away and faint, though it was still clear and resonant in its own peculiar way and very fine and sweet.
column3: I looked at it so closely that a dream came upon my eyes, so that the voice of the Singing Mouse sounded far away and faint, though it was still clear and resonant in its own peculiar way and very fine and sweet.

column2: I will tell you which trophy you most prize, it said.
column3: I will tell you which trophy you most prize, it said.

column2: I will show you your _Iliad_ of the chase.	I will show you your underscore Iliad underscore of the chase.
column3: false

column2: Do you not remember, do you not see this, the most eventful hunting of all your life?"
column3: Do you not remember, do you not see this, the most eventful hunting of all your life?"

column2: And so I gazed where the Singing Mouse pointed, quite beyond the dusty walls, and there I saw as it had said.
column3: And so I gazed where the Singing Mouse pointed, quite beyond the dusty walls, and there I saw as it had said.

column2: I heard not the thunder of the hoofs of buffalo, nor the faint crack of the twig beneath the panther's foot.
column3: I heard not the thunder of the hoofs of buffalo, nor the faint crack of the twig beneath the panther's foot.

column2: I saw not the lurching gallop of the long-jawed wolf, nor the high, elastic bounding of the deer.
column3: I saw not the lurching gallop of the long jawed wolf, nor the high, elastic bounding of the deer.

column2: The level swinging speed of the antelope, the slinking of the lynx, the crashing flight of the wapiti--no, it was none of these that came to mind; nor did the mountains nor the plains, nor the wilderness of the pines.
column3: The level swinging speed of the antelope, the slinking of the lynx, the crashing flight of the wapiti-no, it was none of these that came to mind; nor did the mountains nor the plains, nor the wilderness of the pines.

column2: But when the Singing Mouse whispered, "Do you see?" I murmured in reply, "I see it all again!"
column3: But when the Singing Mouse whispered, "Do you see?" I murmured in reply, "I see it all again!"

column2: I saw the small, low hills, well covered with short oaks and hazel bushes, which rolled on away from the village, far out, almost to the Delectable Mountains, which are well known to be upon the edge of the world.
column3: I saw the small, low hills, well covered with short oaks and hazel bushes, which rolled on away from the village, far out, almost to the Delectable Mountains, which are well known to be upon the edge of the world.

column2: Through these low hills a winding road led on, a road whose end no man had ever reached, but which went to places where, no doubt, many wonders were--perhaps even to the Delectable Mountains; for so a wise man once had said, his words harkened to with awe.
column3: Through these low hills a winding road led on, a road whose end no man had ever reached, but which went to places where, no doubt, many wonders were-perhaps even to the Delectable Mountains; for so a wise man once had said, his words harkened to with awe.

column2: This was a pleasant road, lined with brave sumacs, with bushes of the wild blackberry, and with small hazel trees which soon would offer fruit for the regular harvest of the fall, this same to be spread for drying on the woodshed roof.
column3: This was a pleasant road, lined with brave sumacs, with bushes of the wild blackberry, and with small hazel trees which soon would offer fruit for the regular harvest of the fall, this same to be spread for drying on the woodshed roof.

column2: It was perhaps wise curiosity as to the crop of nuts which had brought thus far from home these two figures--an enormous distance, perhaps at least a mile beyond what heretofore had been the utmost limit of their wanderings.
column3: It was perhaps wise curiosity as to the crop of nuts which had brought thus far from home these two figures-an enormous distance, perhaps at least a mile beyond what heretofore had been the utmost limit of their wanderings.

column2: It was not, perhaps, safe to venture so far.
column3: It was not, perhaps, safe to venture so far.

column2: There were known to be strange creatures in these woods, one knew not what.
column3: There were known to be strange creatures in these woods, one knew not what.

column2: It was therefore well that the younger boy should clasp tightly the hand of the older, him who bore with such confidence the bow and arrows, potent weapons of those days gone by!
column3: It was therefore well that the younger boy should clasp tightly the hand of the older, him who bore with such confidence the bow and arrows, potent weapons of those days gone by!

column2: [Illustration]
column3: [Illustration]

column2: It was half with fear and half with curiosity that these two wandered on, along this mysterious road, through this wild and unknown wilderness, so far from any habitation of mankind.
column3: It was half with fear and half with curiosity that these two wandered on, along this mysterious road, through this wild and unknown wilderness, so far from any habitation of mankind.

column2: The zeal of the explorer held them fast.
column3: The zeal of the explorer held them fast.

column2: They scarce dared fare farther on, but yet would not turn back.
column3: They scarce dared fare farther on, but yet would not turn back.

column2: The noises of the woods thrilled them.
column3: The noises of the woods thrilled them.

column2: The sudden clanging note of the jay near by caused them to stop, heart in mouth for the moment.
column3: The sudden clanging note of the jay near by caused them to stop, heart in mouth for the moment.

column2: Strange rustlings in the leaves made them cross the road, and step more quickly.
column3: Strange rustlings in the leaves made them cross the road, and step more quickly.

column2: Yet the cawing of a crow across the woods seemed friendly, and a small brown bird which hopped ahead along the road was intimate and kind, and thus touched the founts of bravery in the two venturous hearts.
column3: Yet the cawing of a crow across the woods seemed friendly, and a small brown bird which hopped ahead along the road was intimate and kind, and thus touched the founts of bravery in the two venturous hearts.

column2: Certainly they would go on. It was no matter about the sun.
column3: Certainly they would go on. It was no matter about the sun

column2: This was the valley of Ajalon, perhaps, of which one had heard in the class at Sabbath-school. And surely this was a good, droning, yellow-bodied bee--where did the bees go to when they rose up straight into the air?
column3: This was the valley of Ajalon, perhaps, of which one had heard in the class at Sabbath school. And surely this was a good, droning, yellow bodied bee-where did the bees go to when they rose up straight into the air?

column2: And this little mouse, what became of it in winter?
column3: And this little mouse, what became of it in winter?

column2: And--ah!
column3: And-ah!

column2: What was that--that awful burst of sound?
column3: What was that-that awful burst of sound?

column2: Clutch closer, little brother, though both be pale!
column3: Clutch closer, little brother, though both be pale!

column2: How should either of you yet know the thunderous flight of the wild grouse, this great bird which whirled away through the brown leaves of the oaks?
column3: How should either of you yet know the thunderous flight of the wild grouse, this great bird which whirled away through the brown leaves of the oaks?

column2: Father must be asked about this tremendous, startling bird.
column3: Father must be asked about this tremendous, startling bird.

column2: Meantime, the heart having begun to beat again, let the two adventurers press yet a little farther on.
column3: Meantime, the heart having begun to beat again, let the two adventurers press yet a little farther on.

column2: And so, with fears and tremblings, with doubts and joys, through briers and flowers, through hindrances and recompenses, along this crooked, winding, unknown road which led on out into the Unknown, they wandered, as in life we all are wandering to-day.
column3: And so, with fears and tremblings, with doubts and joys, through briers and flowers, through hindrances and recompenses, along this crooked, winding, unknown road which led on out into the Unknown, they wandered, as in life we all are wandering to day.

column2: [Illustration]
column3: [Illustration]

column2: But hush!
column3: But hush!

column2: Listen!
column3: Listen!

column2: What is it, this sound, approaching, coming directly toward the road?
column3: What is it, this sound, approaching, coming directly toward the road?

column2: Surely, it must be the footfall of some large animal, this cadenced rustling on the leaves!
column3: Surely, it must be the footfall of some large animal, this cadenced rustling on the leaves!

column2: It comes--it will cross near--there, it has turned, it is near the road!
column3: It comes-it will cross near-there, it has turned, it is near the road!

column2: Look!
column3: Look!

column2: There it is, a great animal, half the length of one's arm, with bushy, long red tail arched high for easier running, its grayish coat showing in the bars of sunlight, its eyes bright and black and keen.
column3: There it is, a great animal, half the length of one's arm, with bushy, long red tail arched high for easier running, its grayish coat showing in the bars of sunlight, its eyes bright and black and keen.

column2: Had it not been said there were wild animals in these woods?
column3: Had it not been said there were wild animals in these woods?

column2: Each heart now thumped hard with the surging blood it bore; but it was now the blood of hunters and not of boys.
column3: Each heart now thumped hard with the surging blood it bore; but it was now the blood of hunters and not of boys.

column2: Fear vanished at the sight of the quarry, and the only thought remaining was that of battle and of victory.
column3: Fear vanished at the sight of the quarry, and the only thought remaining was that of battle and of victory.

column2: Well for the animal that it ran--ill for it that it ran down the road and not back into the cover.
column3: Well for the animal that it ran-ill for it that it ran down the road and not back into the cover.

column2: The bow twanged, the arrow flew--blunt, but keenly sped. Down went the smitten prey!
column3: The bow twanged, the arrow flew-blunt, but keenly sped. Down went the smitten prey!

column2: Paean!
column3: Paean!

column2: Forward!
column3: Forward!

column2: Victory!
column3: Victory!

column2: But ho! the creature rallies--recovers!
column3: But ho! the creature rallies-recovers!

column2: It gathers its forces, it flies!
column3: It gathers its forces, it flies!

column2: Pursuit then, but pursuit apparently useless, for the animal has found refuge deep in this hollow stump, beyond the reach of longest mortal arm!
column3: Pursuit then, but pursuit apparently useless, for the animal has found refuge deep in this hollow stump, beyond the reach of longest mortal arm!

column2: Rustle now, ye leaves, and threaten now, all ye boughs with menacings.
column3: Rustle now, ye leaves, and threaten now, all ye boughs with menacings.

column2: Roar, grouse, and clamor on, all ye jangling jays.
column3: Roar, grouse, and clamor on, all ye jangling jays.

column2: No longer can ye strike terror into these two souls, small though they be.
column3: No longer can ye strike terror into these two souls, small though they be.

column2: The heart of the hunter has now been born for each. Fear and defeat are known no longer in the compass of their thoughts.
column3: The heart of the hunter has now been born for each. Fear and defeat are known no longer in the compass of their thoughts.

column2: Follow, follow, follow!
column3: Follow, follow, follow!

column2: So spake the good old savagery of the natural man.
column3: So spake the good old savagery of the natural man.

column2: Better for this creature had it never disturbed these two with its footfalls approaching among the leaves.
column3: Better for this creature had it never disturbed these two with its footfalls approaching among the leaves.

column2: Out of its refuge now must it come.
column3: Out of its refuge now must it come.

column2: Yea, though one lost a thousand suppers that night, and though a thousand stones lay waiting in the dark along the road to hurt bare, unprotected toes.
column3: Yea, though one lost a thousand suppers that night, and though a thousand stones lay waiting in the dark along the road to hurt bare, unprotected toes.

column2: The sun forgot its part, and sank red, though reluctant, beyond the Delectable Mountains.
column3: The sun forgot its part, and sank red, though reluctant, beyond the Delectable Mountains.

column2: Thou moon, this is Ajalon!
column3: Thou moon, this is Ajalon!

column2: Be kindly, for by moonlight one still may labor, and here is labor to be done.
column3: Be kindly, for by moonlight one still may labor, and here is labor to be done.

column2: Every blade in the Barlow knives is broken.
column3: Every blade in the Barlow knives is broken.

column2: The hole in the stump yields not to slashings, nor to attempts to pry it open.
column3: The hole in the stump yields not to slashings, nor to attempts to pry it open.

column2: The prey is still unreached.
column3: The prey is still unreached.

column2: What is to be done?
column3: What is to be done?

column2: The elder hunter bethinks him of a solution for this problem. The broken blade will do to gnaw off this bough, and it will serve to make a split in the end of it.
column3: The elder hunter bethinks him of a solution for this problem. The broken blade will do to gnaw off this bough, and it will serve to make a split in the end of it.

column2: And if one be fortunate, and if this split bestride the tail of the concealed animal, and if the stick be twisted--
column3: And if one be fortunate, and if this split bestride the tail of the concealed animal, and if the stick be twisted-

column2: I've got him! cried this philosopher for his "Eureka." And then there was twisting and pulling, and scratching and squeaking, and bitten fingers and tears; but after all was over, there lay the squirrel vanquished, at the feet of these young barbarians who had wandered out from home into the unknown lands of earth.
column3: I've got him! cried this philosopher for his "Eureka." And then there was twisting and pulling, and scratching and squeaking, and bitten fingers and tears; but after all was over, there lay the squirrel vanquished, at the feet of these young barbarians who had wandered out from home into the unknown lands of earth.

column2: Cruel barbarians, thoughtless, relentless!
column3: Cruel barbarians, thoughtless, relentless!

column2: But how much has the world changed?
column3: But how much has the world changed?

column2: The moon was over Ajalon when these two hunters, after all the perils of the long, black road, marched up into the dooryard, bearing on a pole between them their quarry, well suspended by the gambrels.
column3: The moon was over Ajalon when these two hunters, after all the perils of the long, black road, marched up into the dooryard, bearing on a pole between them their quarry, well suspended by the gambrels.

column2: My boys, I feared that you were lost! exclaims the tearful mother who stands waiting in the door. But the silent father, standing back of her in the glow of the lamplight, sees what the pole is bearing, and in his eye there is a smile.
column3: My boys, I feared that you were lost! exclaims the tearful mother who stands waiting in the door. But the silent father, standing back of her in the glow of the lamplight, sees what the pole is bearing, and in his eye there is a smile.

column2: After that, motherly reproach, fatherly inquiry, plenteous bread and milk, many eager explanations and much descriptive narrative simultaneously uttered by two mouths eager both to eat and to talk.
column3: After that, motherly reproach, fatherly inquiry, plenteous bread and milk, many eager explanations and much descriptive narrative simultaneously uttered by two mouths eager both to eat and to talk.

column2: I see it all, I said to the Singing Mouse.
column3: I see it all, I said to the Singing Mouse.

column2: It all comes back again.	It all comes back again.

column2: No chase was ever or will ever be so great as this one--back there, near the Delectable Mountains, in those days gone by, those incomparable days of youth!
column3: No chase was ever or will ever be so great as this one-back there, near the Delectable Mountains, in those days gone by, those incomparable days of youth!

column2: I thank you, Singing Mouse; but I beg you do not go for yet a time.
column3: I thank you, Singing Mouse; but I beg you do not go for yet a time.

column2: One night the moon was shining brightly upon the curtain, which had been drawn tight across the window.
column3: One night the moon was shining brightly upon the curtain, which had been drawn tight across the window.

column2: Within the room the light was dim, so that there could be seen clearly the pictures which the moon was drawing on the curtain, figures which marched, advanced, receded.
column3: Within the room the light was dim, so that there could be seen clearly the pictures which the moon was drawing on the curtain, figures which marched, advanced, receded.

column2: One might almost have thought these the shadows of some moving boughs, had one not known the ways the moon has at certain times.
